column8: has been proposed as a new reference point for the early Solar System timescale and for calculation of the revised minimum age of our Solar System. The Pb-Pb age of SAH of 4566.18 ± 0.14 Ma

column14: despite the fact that the relative <SUP>53</SUP>Mn- <SUP>53</SUP>Cr and <SUP>182</SUP>Hf- <SUP>182</SUP>W ages of these meteorites are identical. Here I report U-Pb data for 21 whole rock and pyroxene fractions from SAH
column15: analyzed using the same approach as D'Orbigny (Amelin
column16: 2008). These fractions contain between 1.3 and 8.9 pg of total common Pb
column17: slightly more than analytical blank. Measured <SUP>206</SUP>Pb/ <SUP>204</SUP>Pb ratios are between 625 and 2817 for D'Orbigny
column18: blank-corrected <SUP>206</SUP>Pb/ <SUP>204</SUP>Pb ratios are between 1173 and 6675. Eight acid-washed whole rock fractions yielded an isochron age of 4564.86 ± 0.38 Ma

column20: and do not form a linear array in <SUP>207</SUP>Pb/ <SUP>206</SUP>Pb vs. <SUP>204</SUP>Pb/ <SUP>206</SUP>Pb isochron coordinates. The <SUP>207</SUP>Pb <SUP>∗</SUP>/ <SUP>206</SUP>Pb <SUP>∗</SUP> model dates of the pyroxene fractions vary from 4563.8 ± 0.3 to 4567.1 ± 0.5 Ma. The difference between whole rock and pyroxene U-Pb systematics may be a result of re-distribution of radiogenic Pb at a mineral grain scale several million years after crystallization. Complexities of Sm-Nd
column22: and possibly <SUP>26</SUP>Al- <SUP>26</SUP>Mg mineral systematics of SAH
column24: may be related to the same process that caused the re-distribution of radiogenic Pb. Disturbance of isotopic chronometers renders SAH an imperfect anchor for the early Solar System timescale. The problems with age determination revealed by the studies of SAH call for greater attention in Pb-isotopic dating of angrites and other achondrites.
